titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Political Newspapers from Buenos Aires LSC.1812
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Tiffany-Kay Sangwand in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), with assistance from Kelley Wolfe Bachli, Winter 2008; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cubé.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-05 11:46:49 -0700.

change.item: Updated the catalog record ID in General Note. Added ethical description statement in the Processing Info note.

did.abstract: This collection contains political newspapers published in Buenos Aires, Argentina from 1812 to 1851. Publications contain a range of topics with a focus on Argentine national issues but also include international news. The newspapers are primarily in Spanish, with some English, French, and Latin, beginning shortly after Argentine independence.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Political Newspapers from Buenos Aires (Collection 1812). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Note
processinfo.p: Processed by Tiffany-Kay Sangwand in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), with assistance from Kelley Wolfe Bachli, Winter 2008.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains political newspapers published in Buenos Aires, Argentina from 1812 to 1851. The collection includes the following publications: La abeja argentina, El abogado nacional, Archivo Americano y espiritu de la prensa del mundo, El centinela, Diario de sesiones, El duende de Buenos Ayres, La gazeta de Buenos Ayres/La gaceta de Buenos Aires, La gaceta mercantil, Lucero, El Oficial del Dia, and El observador. In addition, there is one document on medical issues published in Spain and written in Latin in 1786, entitled Quaestiones medicae sortitae et lege praefixo 10 dier. Termino typis mandatae.

The collection is primarily in Spanish, with some English, French, and Latin, and cover Argentine social, political, economic, commercial, governmental, religious, and cultural issues. Researchers interested in international issues should consult El Archivo Americano y Espiritu de la Prensa del Mundo, El Abogado Nacional, La Gazeta de Buenos Ayres, and Lucero. Researchers with interest in the caudillo dictator Juan Manuel de Rosas should consult El Archivo Americano y Espiritu de la Prensa del Mundo, La Gaceta Mercantil, and Lucero. Researchers interested in Bolivar should consult El Duende de Buenos Ayres.

Coverage of news regarding Buenos Aires, both province and city, is particularly strong throughout the collection and demonstrates the many newspaper sources dating from shortly after Argentine independence through the mid-19th century.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetical by publication title and chronologically within each title.

Box 1 contains La abeja argentina, El abogado nacional, Archivo americano y espiritu de la prensa del mundo, El centinela, El duende de Buenos Ayres, La gazeta de Buenos Ayres/La gaceta de Buenos Aires, El oficial del dia, and El observador. The folders are arranged alphabetically by name of publication and chronologically within each folder.

Box 2 contains Diario de Sesiones from Buenos Aires and Rio de la Plata. They are organized by location and chronologically. Box 2 also contains the item in the Miscellaneous series, Quaestiones medicae sortitae et lege praefixo 10 dier. Termino typis mandatae.
Box 3 contains La gaceta mercantile. Each issue is in a separate folder in chronological order.
Box 4 contains the bound volume of Lucero organized in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: La Abeja Argentina began publishing in 1822; the collection's run includes their premiere issue. It published articles relating to the political and economic independence of Argentina with a focus on the political and economic situation of the province of Buenos Aires.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Number 1 (April 15?), 2 (2 copies, one with cover, May 15), 3 (June 15), 4 (July 15)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: El Abogado Nacional was a bi-weekly publication printed in Spanish by Imprenta de la Independencia. The collection contains four issues from January to March 1819. The first three issues contain a letter to the editor and his response. All the articles pertain to national and international politics, particularly that in Spain, the United States, and Venezuela. The last section of the publication consists of notices of items for sale. This series also contains a bonus publication released on February 19, 1820 regarding a military proclamation.

unittitle.title: El Archivo Americano y Espiritu de la Prensa del Mundo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: El Archivo Americano y Espiritu de la Prensa del Mundo was a publication edited by Pedro de Angeles who was in favor of the dictator Juan Manuel de Rosas. It was published by Imprenta de la Independencia and contained articles, official documents, national and international news. It also includes correspondence between Rosas and British minister Sir Henry Southern. It was the most important organ for the dissemination of the ideas and policies of Rosas in the United States and Europe. Articles were published in Spanish, English and French; some are translations into Spanish.

unittitle.title: El Archivo Americano y Espiritu de la Prensa del Mundo
El Archivo Americano y Espiritu de la Prensa del Mundo
El Archivo Americano y Espiritu de la Prensa del Mundo
El Archivo Americano y Espiritu de la Prensa del Mundo
El Archivo Americano y Espiritu de la Prensa del Mundo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains one incomplete issue of El Centinela dated February 9, 1823. The publication includes an 1822 treasury report for Buenos Aires, a letter to the editor on church reform, an article in favor of the government of Bernadino Rivadavia (1780-1845) and poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: El Correo Judicial was a semi-weekly publication printed in Spanish by Imprenta de la Libertad. The collection contains seven issues published from August to October 1834. The publication was edited by jurist Bernardo Velez and contained articles on legal cases related to commerce.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes legislative journals Diario de Sesiones de la Junta de Representantes de la Provincia de Buenos Aires, Diario de Sesiones del Congreso Nacional de las Provincias Unidas del Rio de la Plata, and Diario de Sesiones del Congreso General Constituyente de las Provincias Unidas del Rio de la Plata. These journals contain the "minutes" of legislative sessions, transcriptions of debates, texts of decrees and resolutions, and cabinet reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: El Duende de Buenos Ayres was a weekly newspaper that published various articles and documents on Bolivar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: La Gaceta Mercantil: Diario commercial, politico y literario was a daily publication running from 1823-1852. It provides a detailed glimpse into the political and commercial life of 19th century Buenos Aires as well as the literary, intellectual and cultural life of the province. It was edited by Stephen Hallet, an Irish-born printer living in Buenos Aires and includes articles, editorials, minutes of government sessions, international news, letters to the editor, poetry, ship arrivals, mail schedule, weather and time of sunrise and sunset, and announcements in Spanish and English. Announcements include help wanted, lost and found, sale, event announcements, change of address, auction and estate sales, and real estate sales. The articles are written from a strong pro-Rosas, federalist perspective The March 31, 1840 issue contains a papal letter of Gregory XVI that forbids slave trade; the letter was printed in English and Latin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: La Gazeta de Buenos Ayres, which changed its name to La Gaceta de Buenos Aires in 1820, is the oldest run of newspapers in the collection. The series contains an incomplete run of newspapers from January 10, 1812 to June 28, 1820; the majority of the issues are from 1818 to 1820. La Gazeta de Buenos Aires was a weekly newspaper printed in Spanish by Imprenta de los Niños Expósitos, which was shortened to Imprenta de los Expositos in 1818. The articles and letters to the editor generally pertain to politics in Argentina, South America and Europe. Topics include the military exploits of Napoleon and Bolivar, the Inquisition in Spain, and political affairs in France, England, Spain, Portugal, and Chile. The end of the publication includes ship arrivals and departures and notices of items wanted and for sale. This section also includes notices on slaves that were missing and for sale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Number 19 (1812 January 10), 41 (1816 February 3), 66 (1816 August 3), Extraordinaria (1817 February 5)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lucero: Diario Politico, Literario, y Mercantil was a daily publication edited by Pedro de Angelis (1784-1859), a Neapolitan émigré who became one of Argentina's early historians. He edited and published a number of important historical documents and published Crónica política y literaria de Buenos Aires (1829), in addition to Lucero. He is often reviled by contemporary historians for his work in support of Rosas during the dictator's rule. Lucero contained national and international new, police news, official documents, general announcements, and notices of auctions and sales.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: El Observador Americano was a weekly publication published by Manuel Antonio Castro, a jurist who advocated judicial reorganization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: El Oficial del Dia was a weekly publication edited by Cayetano Jose Rodriguez, an Argentine cleric, journalist and poet. He was elected to the Assembly of 1813, the General Constituent Assembly of 1813, and as Buenos Aires representative to the Tucuman Congress of 1815. Rodriguez founded the publication in order to defend the Church from the attacks by El Centinela.

unittitle.title: Quaestiones medicae sortitae et lege praefixo 10 dier. Termino typis mandatae

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Document on medical issues published in Spain and written in Latin in 1786
